questions.question_text: Which of the following attacks can be used to exploit a vulnerability that was created by untrained users?

discussion.content: I think A is correct reason being untrained users tends fall in to Phishing emails and Attachments

comments.content: Agree. But technically, the untrained user did not cause the vulnerability. The user would have caused the exploit, but not the vulnerability that allowed the exploit.

choices.C: An evil twin wireless access point
choices.D: A domain hijacking of a bank website
choices.A: A spear-phishing email with a file attachment

questions.question_text: An organization is struggling to differentiate threats from normal traffic and access to systems. A security engineer has been asked to recommend a system that will aggregate data and provide metrics that will assist in identifying malicious actors or other anomalous activity throughout the environment. Which of the following solutions should the engineer recommend?

discussion.content: SIEM is the correct Answer

choices.B: The vendor has not published security patches recently.
choices.A: The device will no longer turn on and indicated an error.
choices.D: Logs show a performance degradation of the component.
choices.C: The object has been removed from the Active Directory.

comments.content: D1960 is misleading with stupid comments... this is a fact

Dooz stop misleading people with your stupid comment. If a device will turn on and indicated an error, then clearly the device is broken. I cannot imagine a more clear indication of end-of-life than a device that will not work.
The answer is very clearly A!

discussion.content: D1960 stop misleading people with these stupid comments, find something better to do with your life. The answer is very clearly B!

Selected Answer: B
"The following list represents products retiring or reaching the end of support in 2020. Upon retirement or end of support, there will be no new security updates, non-security updates, free or paid assisted support options or online technical content updates."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/lifecycle/end-of-support/end-of-support-2020

comments.content: Absolutely not, I think you're taking end-of-life literally. I wouldn't scrap my 2022 Bmw because it wont start.

discussion.content: Best answer to me is A
End-of-life is reference to systems life cycle. It's B.

A. The device will no longer turn on and indicated an error.

Especially if it is an inexpensive and/or older device. I would say that indicates end-of-life. Probably not worth fixing.

B. The vendor has not published security patches recently.

"Recently?" Like in the past two weeks? I don't think that indicates end-of-life.

C. The object has been removed from the Active Directory.

May not mean anything.

D. Logs show a performance degradation of the component.

If the degradation is not especially serious. I don't think that indicates end-of-life.
I think its not B because " Recantlly"

comments.content: I think B is the worst answer there. Answers A and C both make more sense.

questions.question_text: Which of the following may indicate a configuration item has reached end-of-life?

discussion.content: A. What is a Security Playbook? A playbook is a list of required steps and actions needed to successfully respond to any incident or threat. It took more than 30minutes to act, the incident playbook should be updated for future incidents.
Agree with A

Selected Answer: A
A. Updating the playbook with better decision points

Selected Answer: A
Updating security playbook
A. Updating the playbook with better decision points
its A. updating the security playbook
I agree, it's A
Going with A on this one
why not D??

comments.content: Not D because depending on the host it might not be possible or logical to quarantine it. That’s why having a good playbook is important. Helps you respond to specific scenarios efficiently. A is the answer.
Because the issue was that it took more than 30 minutes to quarantine the host. We want them to to determine and do this sooner.

questions.question_text: The SOC is reviewing processes and procedures after a recent incident. The review indicates it took more than 30 minutes to determine that quarantining an infected host was the best course of action. This allowed the malware to spread to additional hosts before it was contained. Which of the following would BEST to improve the incident response process?

choices.A: Updating the playbook with better decision points
choices.C: Providing additional end-user training on acceptable use
choices.D: Implementing manual quarantining of infected hosts
choices.B: Dividing the network into trusted and untrusted zones

discussion.content:
A.
This CASP question is on SEC+ now.
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/comptia/view/43949-exam-sy0-601-topic-1-question-134-discussion/
It's A.
you both submitted and then commented that the answer you gave was wrong.

comments.content: If it’s internal it’s likely not going through the firewall unless you segment it. Segmentation is correct.
There are such things are internal firewalls. And firewall whitelisting would be effective.

discussion.content: How is the ans segmentation, firewall whitelisting is the ans

questions.question_text: A large industrial system's smart generator monitors the system status and sends alerts to third-party maintenance personnel when critical failures occur. While reviewing the network logs, the company's security manager notices the generator's IP is sending packets to an internal file server's IP. Which of the following mitigations would be BEST for the security manager to implement while maintaining alerting capabilities?
